title: du Bois Score for Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) Mortality
description: Determines 1-year mortality risk in IPF patients using PFT and clinical indicators. Developed from two clinical trials (n=1,099) to identify independent predictors of 1-year mortality in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

parameters.name: respiratory_hospitalization
parameters.description: History of respiratory hospitalization within the past 6 months

parameters.name: fvc_percent_predicted
parameters.description: Forced vital capacity (FVC) as percentage of predicted value

parameters.name: change_fvc_24_weeks
parameters.description: Change in FVC over 24 weeks (absolute change in % predicted)

result.name: du_bois_score
result.description: du Bois mortality risk score for IPF patients

ranges.interpretation: Low risk of 1-year mortality in IPF. Continue standard monitoring and treatment. Regular follow-up with pulmonary function tests and clinical assessment recommended.

Intermediate risk of 1-year mortality in IPF. Consider more frequent monitoring, optimization of antifibrotic therapy, and evaluation for lung transplantation if appropriate. Discuss prognosis and advance care planning.

High risk of 1-year mortality in IPF. Urgent consideration for lung transplantation evaluation if candidate. Optimize supportive care, consider palliative care consultation, and discuss advance directives. Close monitoring required.

references: du Bois RM, Weycker D, Albera C, Bradford WZ, Costabel U, Kartashov A, et al. Ascertainment of individual risk of mortality for patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2011;184(4):459-66. doi: 10.1164/rccm.201011-1790OC.

Ley B, Ryerson CJ, Vittinghoff E, Ryu JH, Tomassetti S, Lee JS, et al. A multidimensional index and staging system for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Ann Intern Med. 2012;156(10):684-91. doi: 10.7326/0003-4819-156-10-201205150-00004.

Raghu G, Collard HR, Egan JJ, Martinez FJ, Behr J, Brown KK, et al. An official ATS/ERS/JRS/ALAT statement: idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: evidence-based guidelines for diagnosis and management. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2011;183(6):788-824. doi: 10.1164/rccm.2009-040GL.
formula: du Bois Score = Age points + Respiratory hospitalization points + FVC % predicted points + FVC change points. Age: 51-60 years (1 pt), 61-70 years (2 pts), >70 years (3 pts). Recent respiratory hospitalization: Yes (2 pts). FVC % predicted: 50-65% (1 pt), <50% (2 pts). FVC decline >10% in 24 weeks: Yes (3 pts).
notes: Developed from data of 1,099 IPF patients from two clinical trials to predict 1-year mortality.
Score ranges from 0-10 points with higher scores indicating increased mortality risk.

Higher scores correlate with increased 1-year mortality risk in IPF patients.
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and other prognostic factors.
Consider lung transplantation evaluation for high-risk patients who are candidates.
Regular monitoring of pulmonary function tests is essential for IPF management.
This tool aids in prognosis assessment but does not replace comprehensive clinical evaluation.
